Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Caudal Adjuvants in Pediatric Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: 63 children aged 1–6 years with ASA physical status I or II were randomised

Participants.evidence: 63 children aged 1–6 years with ASA physical status I or II were randomised to receive a caudal block

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive a caudal block with either dexmedetomidine 1 μg/kg (Group D), morphine 30 μg/kg (Group M), or clonidine 1.5 μg/kg (Group C), along with 0.2% ropivacaine

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the duration of postoperative analgesia provided by morphine, clonidine, and dexmedetomidine

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the duration of analgesia, measured until the first rescue analgesic was required

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors

Number_Randomised.evidence: 63 children aged 1–6 years with ASA physical status I or II were randomised

Result_Outcome.evidence: The median duration of analgesia was 380 minutes for Group D, 360 minutes for Group C, and 405 minutes for Group M, with no statistically significant difference (P = 0.843)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included intraoperative hypotension in 43.5% of Group D, 27.8% of Group C, and 22.7% of Group M (P = 0.299)
